translation.en: [man] ♪ Somebody have mercy on me ♪
♪ Somebody have mercy on me right now ♪
[Smokey] Sam had that magic voice.
♪ I wanna tell you that, darling, you... ♪
♪ Oh-oh-oh ♪
♪ You send me... ♪
[second man] Sam is the father of modern soul music. Absolutely.
translation.ko: 샘은 모던 소울 뮤직의 아버지예요 그렇고 말고요

translation.en: This is Sam singing to a black audience.
It's a vastly different kind of Sam Cooke than the mainstream,
translation.ko: 샘 쿡의 노래는 백인들에게 익숙했던 주류 음악과

translation.en: meaning white people, have become accustomed to.
♪ I love you ♪ ♪ For ♪
♪ Sentimental reasons ♪
People remember Sam Cooke as a pristine Frank Sinatra wannabe.
translation.ko: 사람들은 샘을 프랭크 시내트라를 흉내 낸 가수로 기억해요

translation.en: But in reality, he was a complicated black man in a complicated world.
translation.ko: 하지만 실상은 복잡한 세상에 사는 복잡한 흑인 남자였어요

translation.en: Record companies really did not want a black man
translation.ko: 나라에서 일어나는 문제들을 흑인들이 이야기하는 건 음반사가 꺼려했어요

translation.en: talking about issues that were going on in the country.
They wanted him to be an entertainer and nothing more,
translation.ko: 엔터테이너 이상이 되는 건 바라지 않았어요

translation.en: and that was never gonna be enough for Sam Cooke.
translation.ko: 샘 쿡은 거기에 만족할 리 없었고요

translation.en: ♪ How many deaths will it take ♪
♪Till you know ♪ ♪ Too many people have died ? ♪
translation.ko: 얼마나 많은 사람이 죽었는지 알 때까지...

translation.en: In the times where everything was so oppressive,
he broke through a lot of color barriers and wasn't afraid to be the first.
translation.ko: 당당하게 선두에 서서 인종 간의 장벽을 무너뜨렸어요

translation.en: Empowerment--this is what drove him to talk with Malcolm X and Muhammad Ali.
translation.ko: 맬컴 X와 무하마드 알리와 함께 '인권 신장'을 이야기했어요

translation.en: He was so unafraid.
If you afraid, you couldn't be hangin' out with Malcolm, but...
the FBI might find a way to get rid of you.
These were the early stages of black power.
That black male energy that Sam Cooke possessed,
translation.ko: 샘 쿡이 가진 흑인 남성의 에너지가

translation.en: unfortunately, for some people in power in this country,
represented a threat that had to be stopped.
This very mysterious death was just the most improbable death for Sam Cooke.
translation.ko: 의문사였어요, 샘 쿡이 그렇게 허망하게 죽을 리 없었어요

translation.en: What happened? Why was he there? And who was this woman he was with?
translation.ko: 어떻게 된 거고, 거기에 왜 있었고 같이 있었던 여자는 누군지

translation.en: And why'd he get shot? All those become bigger questions
than "What was he on the edge of achieving?"
translation.ko: 샘 쿡이 성취하려 했던 바보다 더 주목받았죠

translation.en: It's a double murder.
translation.ko: "샘 쿡 살인 사건 정당방위로 판결 팬들 격분하다"

translation.en: It's the murder of the physical being who was Sam Cooke,
translation.ko: 두 번 죽인 거죠 살아 움직이던 샘 쿡의 육체뿐만이 아니라

translation.en: but there's also the murder of his legacy.
translation.ko: 살아 움직이던 샘 쿡의 육체뿐만이 아니라 그의 음악적 유산까지 죽였어요

translation.en: One of the biggest shocks I ever had in my life.
I was on the expressway in Detroit, and the radio was on.
Soul singer Sam Cooke shot to death last night...
translation.ko: 샘 쿡이 어젯밤에 총에 맞아 사망했다고 했죠

translation.en: in Compton or wherever he was.
I was devastated.
I don't think I functioned for a week.
translation.ko: "제리 브랜트 부팀장 & 기획자" 일주일 정도는 제정신이 아니었죠

translation.en: It was horrible.
I asked my father
translation.ko: 샘이 죽었다는 이야기를 아버지한테 전해 듣고

translation.en: when he told me he was dead, I said, "What, a car accident?
translation.ko: 샘이 죽었다는 이야기를 아버지한테 전해 듣고 "빌리 데이비스 뮤지션 / 친구" 차 사고인가 했어요 비행기 추락이나요

translation.en: A plane crash?"
I couldn't-- Even when he told me he got shot, I...
translation.ko: 총에 맞았단 걸 믿을 수가 없었어요

translation.en: I could've just passed out.
Who would want to shoot Sam Cooke? That's what I asked myself.
translation.ko: 누가 샘 쿡을 죽이려 했을까? 자문해 봤죠

translation.en: I was sad and confused back then,
and most-- other people, especially in the black community, but not only,
translation.ko: "월터 모슬리 작가" 대부분 그랬지만 특히 흑인 사회 사람들이

translation.en: were sad and confused. You know, "What happened?"
Everybody was cold but anxiously waiting.
They wanted to see Sam Cooke.
They wanted to know if this really happened.
translation.ko: "스펜서 리크 리크 & 선스 장례식장" 실제 상황인지 알고 싶어 했어요

translation.en: There was just disbelief and sorrow all mixed up.
Two hundred thousand people-plus showed up at his funeral in Chicago,
translation.ko: 시카고에서 치른 장례식에 20만 명 넘게 왔어요

translation.en: and this is how this man died,
you know, naked at a seedy hotel in Los Angeles.
translation.ko: LA에 있는 어느 지저분한 호텔에서 나체로 죽었어요 "케빈 파월 작가 / 활동가"

translation.en: He's one of the biggest pop stars in America,
translation.ko: 미국에서 유명한 팝 스타가 갑자기 의문사했으니 이상했죠

translation.en: and he's just mysteriously dead now. Didn't make any sense.
translation.ko: 미국에서 유명한 팝 스타가 갑자기 의문사했으니 이상했죠 "통곡하는 팬들 샘 쿡을 애도하다"

translation.en: Muhammad Ali, in his grief and rage, essentially said,
"If this had happened to Frank Sinatra or The Beatles or Ricky Nelson,
translation.ko: "러네이 그레이엄 보스턴글로브 부편집장" '프랭크 시내트라나 비틀스 리키 넬슨이 이렇게 됐다면'

translation.en: the FBI would be investigating this."
'Cause, of course, it felt this all went way too quickly.
translation.ko: 상황이 너무 빠르게 진행되는 듯 했어요

translation.en: And Muhammad Ali, I think, spoke for the entire community
translation.ko: 무하마드 알리의 말처럼 흑인 사회 전체가

translation.en: who believed that this was being treated as just another dead black person.
translation.ko: "캐시어스 클레이 사건 조사에 억울함 호소" 여느 흑인의 사망과 다름없이 다뤄진다고 생각했어요

translation.en: Sam Cooke, at the time of his death,
is someone who has significant meaning to the black community.
translation.ko: 흑인 사회에 막중한 영향력을 미치는 사람이었어요 "마크 앤서니 닐 박사" "듀크대학교 아프리카 연구학 교수"

translation.en: Black community loves him.
Sam Cooke didn't mean the same to white America.
They didn't recognize how important Sam Cooke was.
translation.ko: 샘 쿡이 얼마나 중요한 사람인지 알지 못했어요

translation.en: Sam Cooke's death, or at least the way that it's been treated in the media,
translation.ko: 샘 쿡의 죽음으로 앞으로의 가수 경력이

translation.en: it's been allowed to sort of hijack the rest of his career.
translation.ko: 그냥 사라져 버렸죠 적어도 언론은 그렇게 다뤘어요

translation.en: People didn't think of Sam Cooke in that way,
translation.ko: 사람들은 샘 쿡을 그런 식으로 생각하지 않았지만

translation.en: but he's a racial hero as much as he was a musical hero.
Between the way he died and this representation of him
translation.ko: 사망 원인과 샘 쿡이라는 사람을 너무 단순하게 표현한 걸 보면

translation.en: as a sort of almost one-dimensional character
translation.ko: 샘 쿡이라는 사람을 너무 단순하게 표현한 걸 보면

translation.en: kind of loses the essence of who he was.
You have to question
why did the record companies suppress his politics?
translation.ko: 왜 음반사가 샘 쿡의 정치 견해를 억압했을까?

translation.en: ♪ Oh, my baby's comin' home tomorr' ♪
translation.ko: 오 나의 그대가 내일 집으로 돌아온다네

translation.en: ♪ Ain't that good news? ♪ ♪ Man, ain't that news? ♪
translation.ko: 좋은 소식이 아닌가? 그것참 좋은 소식이 아닌가?

translation.en: ♪ Yeah, good news ♪
♪ Good news ♪
♪ Ain't that good news? ♪
♪ Ain't that news? ♪
-Miss Elinor Harris. -Hello, Miss Harris.
-Sam, sit here. -Terrific.
-It's good news. -Good news, yeah.
Let's do a little capsule version of the Sam Cooke story.
translation.ko: 샘 쿡 이야기를 요약 버전으로 들어보죠

translation.en: -How'd it all happen... -The captions version. Uh...
Born. My father was a minister.
Uh, I started singing in the church, naturally,
because I'm exposed to, uh, gospel singing first, Mike.
translation.ko: 아기 때 복음 성가를 듣고 자랐죠

translation.en: Sam Cooke is born in 1931 in Mississippi.
As Sam Cooke was coming of age during the Great Depression,
translation.ko: 대공황 시대를 겪을 때가 그의 나이

translation.en: late '30s into the '40s,
slavery was something that was still a residual memory for many people.
translation.ko: 여전히 많은 사람의 기억에 노예제도가 남아 있었어요

translation.en: You're talking about a time where black people,
translation.ko: 그 당시 상황을 얘기하자면 흑인들, 특히 흑인 남자들이 아무 데서나 구타를 당했어요

translation.en: especially black men, were being lynched all over the place.
translation.ko: 흑인들, 특히 흑인 남자들이 아무 데서나 구타를 당했어요

translation.en: I'm certain that people like Sam Cooke's family,
translation.ko: 목사였던 아버지를 포함해 샘 쿡의 가족같은 사람들은

translation.en: including his father, who was a preacher, said, "We've got to get somewhere
translation.ko: 목사였던 아버지를 포함해 샘 쿡의 가족같은 사람들은 생존에만 급급할 게 아니라

translation.en: where we can have a life for ourselves, where we can actually not just survive,
translation.ko: 사람답게 잘 살 수 있는 그런 곳으로

translation.en: but hopefully, we can win."
My great-grandmother was a slave in Mississippi.
She had no education. Neither did my father.
translation.ko: 증조할머니도 저희 아버지도 교육을 못 받았어요

translation.en: He was a self-made man,
translation.ko: 아버지는 자수성가했죠 "샘 쿡의 인터뷰 날짜 미상"

translation.en: but he saw the disadvantages to the negro child in the South,
translation.ko: 하지만 남부의 흑인 아이들에게 불리한 점들이 있는 걸 봤어요

translation.en: so he went north to Chicago.
In many ways, I'm very like my father.
He has this intense drive that I've got.
Papa Cook got a church in Chicago,
translation.ko: 샘의 아버지가 시카고에 교회를 갖고 있었어요

translation.en: so everybody went to church in his family.
Bronzeville was a beautiful place.
In that corridor, from 43rd and State Street to 51st Street,
there must've been 200 to 300 black businesses that were vibrant.
Segregated, of course. All black.
It was like a black Wall Street.
Churches everywhere on every block.
There is no black politics at this moment in time without the black church.
translation.ko: 그 당시에 흑인 교회가 없으면 정치 활동이 있을 수 없었죠

translation.en: If you were a popular gospel singer, as Sam Cooke eventually would become,
translation.ko: 샘 쿡 같은 유명한 성가대 가수라면 결국에는

translation.en: you would rub elbows with a young Martin Luther King, right?
translation.ko: 젊은 마틴 루서 킹 같은 사람과 거사를 논의했을 거예요

translation.en: You would know who Reverend C.L. Franklin was,
who, of course, is Aretha Franklin's father
and generally regarded as one of the greatest preachers
translation.ko: 어리사 프랭클린의 아버지고 20세기에 배출된 훌륭한 전도사 중 한 명으로 알려진 분이죠

translation.en: produced in the 20th century.
translation.ko: 훌륭한 전도사 중 한 명으로 알려진 분이죠

translation.en: Chicago was a place where people had to figure out how to hustle for themselves,
translation.ko: 시카고에서는 어떻게 잘살지 스스로 궁리해야 했어요

translation.en: and I don't think it's a coincidence that Sam Cooke would eventually say,
translation.ko: 샘 쿡 같은 사람이 이런 말을 한 것도 우연이 아니죠

translation.en: "I want to own my own record label, own my own publishing company."
translation.ko: '내 음반사를 차리고 싶다 내 출판사를 차리고 싶다'

translation.en: That's what you saw in Chicago.
You saw businesses everywhere, and I'm sure he was impacted by that.
translation.ko: 시카고가 그런 곳이었거든요 사업체들이 넘쳤으니 당연히 영향을 받았겠죠

translation.en: Papa Cook-- he knew that Sam was very gifted.
translation.ko: 아버지는 샘의 재능이 출중하단 걸 알았어요

translation.en: Matter of fact, the whole Cook children, 'cause they were called the Cook children.
He took 'em around to the churches to sing.
translation.ko: 아버지가 쿡가 아이들 모두를 교회에 데려가 노래를 시켰어요

translation.en: ♪ Well ♪
♪Oh ♪
♪ Though I've never been up there ♪
I met Sam at a concert in Gary, Indiana.
translation.ko: 인디애나주 게리에서 열린 콘서트에서 샘을 만났어요

translation.en: I was about 16 years old,
and Sam would had to be around 13 or 14.
I went up, and I say, "Hey, man. You were somethin' else, boy."
I ain't never heard nothing like this before in my life."
♪ Does Jesus care? ♪
The Soul Stirrers was a top group. They were one of the biggest.
translation.ko: 솔 스터스는 최고의 그룹 중 하나였어요

translation.en: It was a really big deal when Sam was tapped as a teenager
translation.ko: 십 대인 샘이 RH 해리스의 자리를 대신하는 건

translation.en: to fill the shoes of R. H. Harris,
who was a grown man and had been around the circle.
♪ I no longer stand ♪
♪ I ask my mother how ♪
He starts out trying to sing some of the lead songs the way that Harris did. He was trying to reach--
translation.ko: 처음에는 해리스의 방식을 따라 노래하기 시작했어요

translation.en: As the story goes, he was trying to reach this high note
and couldn't quite reach it the way Harris did,
and he instinctively did this flutter
translation.ko: 대신에 본능적으로 떠는 소리를 낸 거죠

translation.en: where he just kind of reached up for the note and just floated down.
translation.ko: 그 음에 비슷하게 올라갔다가 소리를 떨면서 내려와요

translation.en: ♪ He gave her ♪ ♪ And it was not in the well ♪ -♪ Whoa ♪ -♪ Yes ♪
When you hear a track like "Jesus Gave Me Water,"
you hear Sam keepin' up with the choir, keeping the time,
translation.ko: 샘이 성가대와 맞춰 부르고 박자도 지키면서

translation.en: but then he goes into that little yodel piece, right,
that just says that this is Sam Cooke's song now.
♪ Water, water, water, water, loving water ♪ ♪ And it was not in the well ♪
Aretha Franklin is my longest friend who is still alive.
translation.ko: 어리사 플랭클린은 아직 살아있는 제 가장 오래된 친구고 같이 컸죠

translation.en: We grew up together. Occasionally, I would go to their church,
translation.ko: 어리사 플랭클린은 아직 살아있는 제 가장 오래된 친구고 같이 컸죠 한 번씩 그 교회에 갔는데

translation.en: but when Sam and the Soul Stirrers came to that church,
translation.ko: 샘과 솔 스터스가 교회에 올 때면

translation.en: you would've thought they were gonna have a rock concert there
because-- especially for women.
There were women who never even thought about goin' to church until...
until Sam and the Soul Stirrers were there.
translation.ko: 샘과 솔 스터스 때문에 교회에 나갔죠

translation.en: And they would be around the block four deep, you know,
translation.ko: 네 블럭 건너까지 여자들이 줄지어 있었죠

translation.en: because Sam was there.
♪ Oh, pray when you're feelin' low ♪
translation.ko: 기분이 안 좋을 때는 기도를 해요

translation.en: ♪ When the ill wind blows ♪ ♪ Don't forget to pray ♪
translation.ko: 풍파가 닥쳤을 때 잊지 말고 기도를 해요

translation.en: I believe it was Abyssinia Baptist Church in Newark
translation.ko: 뉴워크에 있는 아비시니아 침례 교회였을 거예요

translation.en: where the Soul Stirrers were a part of the program.
translation.ko: 솔 스터스가 교회 프로그램에 속해 있었어요

translation.en: I thought he was the cutest thing in the world.
I was 11 years old and madly in love.
Sam Cooke joins the Soul Stirrers when he's in his late teens,
translation.ko: 샘 쿡은 십 대 후반에 솔 스터스에 합류했어요

translation.en: so he's 19-20 years old when he starts to go down south to tour.
There was a Chitlin Circuit black artists played back in those days,
translation.ko: 당시 흑인 예술가들이 활동했던 치틀린 서킷이란 데가 있었죠

translation.en: especially through the South.
We called it the Chitlin Circuit 'cause those places
were like funky like that, you know, like, funky like chitlins.
This is the time when we were on the last legs of vaudeville
and on the beginnings of rock 'n' roll,
of-of-of that kind of R&B rock 'n' roll.
translation.ko: 리듬 앤드 블루스나 로큰롤 같은 음악요

translation.en: So a lot of the places that we played
were like not very much bigger than this room.
They had one microphone with five of us tryin' to sing on one microphone.
translation.ko: 마이크 하나에 대고 다섯 명이 노래를 했어요

translation.en: ♪ ...a bad girl be-- ♪
And I'm singing "Bad Girl" into this guy's chest
translation.ko: 다른 사람 가슴에 대고 '나쁜 여자'를 불렀어요

translation.en: because that's how close the crowd--
There was no stage, and we were on the floor,
and I'm singing "Bad Girl" into this guy's chest,
translation.ko: 다른 사람한테 바싹 붙어서 노래를 했죠

translation.en: and people behind him are yellin' and screamin',
translation.ko: 그 사람 뒤에서 사람들이 고함을 질렀어요

translation.en: "Move out of the way. We can't see."
And so that's an example of what some of that stuff was like.
translation.ko: 당시 상황을 예를 들자면 그랬단 말입니다

translation.en: In traveling the South with the Soul Stirrers,
they're dealing with where they can stay,
translation.ko: 솔 스터스와 남부를 여행하면서 숙박지, 식당, 공연장이 문제였어요

translation.en: where they can eat, the audiences they can play to.
At that moment, you know, he's a kid.
He's got to go with what's going on, but it really pained him,
you know, the heavy yoke of-of the Jim Crow laws,
translation.ko: 받아들이는 수밖에 없었지만 정말 힘들었죠 극심한 흑인 차별 정책 때문에요

translation.en: which was something he wasn't really that accustomed to,
but had to get used to pretty quickly.
The conditions were very hard and very prejudice.
translation.ko: 상황이 열악하고 차별이 심했어요 "유색 인종 호텔"

translation.en: There were places in the South where we couldn't even stay in the hotels.
translation.ko: 남부에는 우리는 묵을 수 없는 호텔들도 있었어요

translation.en: We'd have to stay in rooming houses.
We used to have to sleep in mortuaries with six bodies there,
translation.ko: 영안실에서 자기도 했어요 "퀸시 존스 작곡가 / 프로듀서" 시체 6구가 든 관이 있는 곳에서 간이 침대에서 잠을 자야 했어요

translation.en: us sleepin' in a cot with six bodies in caskets, you know.
translation.ko: 시체 6구가 든 관이 있는 곳에서 간이 침대에서 잠을 자야 했어요

translation.en: Sam, he didn't like the Chitlin Circuit
because he wanted to be able to go where he wanted to go, you know.
translation.ko: 원하는 곳에 마음대로 갈 수가 없었으니까요

translation.en: After he went on that tour down south,
he came back, and he says, "Scoe, it's a shame how people is being treated.
translation.ko: 투어 후에 저한테, 사람들이 그런 취급을 받아 안타깝다고 했죠

translation.en: Somebody should do something about it."
So only thing I could say I know what he was talkin' about
translation.ko: 무슨 말인지 이해한다는 말밖에 못 했어요

translation.en: because I had been through the same-- some of the same things myself.
I was comin' from school, and I was on the sidewalk walkin',
translation.ko: 학교 다녀 오는 길에 인도를 걷고 있는데

translation.en: and he...
he hit me and knocked me off the sidewalk, say, "I teach a nigger how to...
translation.ko: 저를 인도 밖으로 밀치더니 백인으로서 검둥이한테

translation.en: how to walk on the sidewalk with a white man."
translation.ko: 인도에서 걷는 법을 가르쳐 주겠다고 하더군요

translation.en: You're talking about a time
where a little black boy, 14 years old, who was also from Chicago,
translation.ko: 샘 쿡처럼 시카고 출신이고 미시시피에 살던

translation.en: with roots in Mississippi, just like Sam Cooke,
Emmet Till allegedly whistled at a white woman,
translation.ko: 에밋 틸이 백인 여자에게 휘파람을 불었다고

translation.en: and he was beaten savagely in Money, Mississippi,
and had a fan tied around his neck and was killed.
Sam and I-- we talked about Emmett Till a lot.
translation.ko: 저와 샘은 에밋 틸 이야기를 자주 했어요

translation.en: We was wondering just how could that be possible?
translation.ko: 어떻게 그런 일이 일어날 수 있는지 의아했어요 "로이드 프라이스 뮤지션 / 친구"

translation.en: We didn't understand it at all.
When we saw the picture, I think Sam felt really hurt on a personal level.
translation.ko: 사진을 보고 샘은 개인적으로 굉장히 마음이 아팠을 거예요

translation.en: Sam thought that there's got to be something that can be done.
translation.ko: 뭐라도 할 수 있는 게 있을 거라고 생각했죠

translation.en: We're living in a world where we pay taxes,
translation.ko: 우리도 세금 내고 법 지키며 사는 세상인데요

translation.en: and we're law-abiding people, you know what I mean?
translation.ko: 우리도 세금 내고 법 지키며 사는 세상인데요 "에밋 틸의 장례식 시카고, 1955년"

translation.en: This should not happen to a 14-year-old anywhere, you know,
translation.ko: 14살짜리에게 그런 일이 일어나선 안 되잖아요 어디에서도요 샘은 굉장히 비통해했어요

translation.en: so he was, like, very bitter about that.
It was a wake-up call,
and it was actually, the really,
the beginning of the Civil Rights movement.
translation.ko: 흑인 민권 운동의 시작이었죠 "소년의 잔혹한 죽음이 시위를 일으키다"

translation.en: Sam had things on his mind that he wanted to do,
translation.ko: 샘이 하려고 마음 먹은 일들이 있었어요

translation.en: and he especially wanted to help his people, our people,
translation.ko: 특히 자기 사람들을 돕고 싶어 했죠

translation.en: and he was determined to do that.
And he told me, "'Scoe, one of these days, the world gonna know Sam Cooke,
translation.ko: 세상 사람들이 자기를 알게 될 거라고 했어요

translation.en: and I'm gonna help my people."
♪ I bought a brand-new airmobile ♪
Sam was a person of the early rock-'n'-roll generation,
so he was hearing Chuck Berry. He was hearing Little Richard.
translation.ko: 척 베리나 리틀 리처드를 바로 뒤따라 갔던 거죠

translation.en: ♪ Oh, now lawdy, lawdy, lawdy, Miss Clawdy ♪
translation.ko: 오, 로디, 로디, 로디 미스 클로디!

translation.en: ♪ Girl, you sure look good to me ♪
I met Sam in Specialty Records' office
They were celebrating "Lawdy, Miss Clawdy"
translation.ko: '로디, 미스 클로디'가 처음으로 백만 장을 판

translation.en: because it was their first rock-'n'-roll record to ever sell a million copies.
Sam would sneak off to rock-'n'-roll shows
because he saw something bigger, you know.
Sam knew all of the joints to go to.
He'd say, "The Soul Stirrers didn't know, but we'd be out
till two or three o'clock in the morning and have to sing the next day."
He'd say, "But Sam would be ready," you know.
When he came to my show at the Apollo, I pointed something out to him.
translation.ko: 아폴로에 제 공연에 샘이 왔을 때 제가 알려줬죠

translation.en: I said, "Now, you had about 300. I got 1,700 in here.
They're doin' the same thing here you had 'em doing in Richmond in church.
There's no different than this."
And he just didn't wanna switch.
But all the gospel singers back during that time didn't wanna switch.
You know, I guess it was because of the fear of Jesus.
We are told straight up in the black church,
"Either you're gonna sing God's music, or you're gonna do the Devil's music."
translation.ko: 하나님의 음악을 할 것인지 악마의 음악을 할 것인지요

translation.en: And there's a kind of a guilt complex that gets tied to that because you're like,
"Well, I wanna sing God's music, but this Devil music's got me dancing.
translation.ko: 하나님의 음악을 하고 싶은데 악마의 음악이 신나니까요

translation.en: And this Devil music can make me famous. I can do more things with my life."
translation.ko: 내가 유명해지고 더 많은 걸 할 수 있으니까요

translation.en: He said himself, "I was afraid at first
because I knew that if I switched over...
if it didn't work, I couldn't come back with the Soul Stirrers."
translation.ko: 솔 스터스로 돌아올 수 없단 걸 아니까요

translation.en: That's the way people were.
Once you went out there, they weren't forgiving.
translation.ko: 그런 식이었어요 일단 나가면 용서하지 않았죠

translation.en: Papa Cook was like my father, you know.
translation.ko: 샘 쿡의 아버지는 제게 아버지 같았어요

translation.en: He said, "Boy, let me tell you something.
You can gain the world...
and lose your soul.
You're doin' good with the Soul Stirrers. Everybody loves you.
You're known all around the country."
But Sam told him, "I want to be known all around the world."
Sam was saying early on, "I wanna make a wide range of music.
translation.ko: 샘은 초기에 다양한 세계 음악을 하고 싶고

translation.en: I wanna appeal to a wide range of people."
Well, why is that? It's about freedom.
I think he understood that whatever he was doing in this period
translation.ko: 그 시기에 본인이 뭘 하든 뒤를 잇는 사람들에게

translation.en: would have an impact on the people who would come after him.
translation.ko: 영향을 미칠 것을 알았을 거예요 "경이로워 솔 스터스"

translation.en: ♪ Wonderful ♪
There was a song called, uh,
♪ Wonderful ♪
♪ Oh-oh-oh ♪ ♪ My God is so wonderful ♪
[Sam] ♪ He's wonderful ♪
♪ Whoa ♪
He took that song and said,
♪ Lovable ♪
♪ She is so lovable ♪
[Sam] ♪ She's so lovable ♪
The first record that he came out with, he didn't use Sam Cooke.
translation.ko: 첫 앨범을 낼 때는 샘 쿡이라는 이름을 안 쓰고

translation.en: He used Dale Cook because he was afraid of the backlash.
translation.ko: 데일 쿡이란 이름을 썼어요 반발을 두려워했거든요

translation.en: We used to, "Man, that's-that's-that's gotta be Sam. I don't know anybody-- I haven't heard anybody who sang like that."
translation.ko: 다들 이렇게 말했어요 '샘이지, 누가 또 저렇게 불러?'

translation.en: ♪ Whoa ♪
At some point, he just made peace with the fact that,
translation.ko: 어느 시점에 스스로 마음을 편하게 먹고

translation.en: "I'm gonna make the kind of music that I wanna make,
and I'm gonna use my name-- C-O-O-K.
I'm gonna add a "E" to it for some flavor,
translation.ko: 끝에 'E'를 붙여 느낌을 좀 주기로 결정했죠

translation.en: you know, special Chicago flavor,
and I'm gonna put out this little song in 1957 called 'You Send Me.'"
[Sam] This is "You Send Me."
♪ You send me ♪
♪ Darling, you send me ♪
Even though it's presented in a much more polished way in "You Send Me,"
you can hear aspects of his gospel background.
translation.ko: 샘 쿡이 받은 가스펠의 영향이 들려요

translation.en: ♪ Honest you do, whoa-oa-oa ♪
That moment where he does the "whoa-oa-oa,"
I mean, it's just, like, fantastic as a signature.
"You Send Me" is one of the most perfect pop songs of the era.
translation.ko: '당신께서 날 보내셨죠'는 당시 가장 완벽한 노래 중 하나죠

translation.en: It's a song that was probably too pop-ish for Elvis Presley.
translation.ko: 엘비스 프레슬리한테는 너무 팝적인 노래였을 거예요

translation.en: When they announced they were gonna have Sam Cooke on Ed Sullivan's show...
translation.ko: 에드 설리번 쇼에 샘 쿡이 출연한다고 발표했을 때

translation.en: we knew that the record was a hit.
For African-Americans, of course there was this great pride.
You know, not everyone has a television, so it wasn't unusual that you might have
translation.ko: 집집마다 TV가 있진 않았어요 흑인 동네에는

translation.en: the one or two families in the black neighborhood that has a television,
translation.ko: 한두 집 정도에 TV가 있는 게 다였죠

translation.en: and everybody shows up at the house
translation.ko: 모두 그 집에 모여서 TV에 나오는 그의 모습을

translation.en: just to catch a glimpse of blackness on television.
translation.ko: 모두 그 집에 모여서 TV에 나오는 그의 모습을 조금이라도 엿보려고 했어요

translation.en: And now, ladies and gentlemen--Sam Cooke.
♪ Darling you ♪
We were all waiting, 30 or 40 people around a little television,
waiting for Sam to come on.
It was like seein' God, really.
♪ Honest you do ♪
It's a gold record commemorating the million-record sale
of your big hit "You Send Me," and here it is.
Ha ha. Thank you, Steve, and I'd like to--
-[applause] -[indistinct chatter]
translation.ko: 고맙습니다, 스티브 정말 고맙습니다 "샘 쿡의 '당신께서 날 보내셨죠' 1,125,000장 판매 돌파"

translation.en: One night, I was singin' in the church
translation.ko: 하루는 교회에서 노래를 하며 따로 일을 해야겠다고 생각했죠

translation.en: and thinkin' maybe I'll have to get a side job.
translation.ko: 하루는 교회에서 노래를 하며 따로 일을 해야겠다고 생각했죠 "샘 쿡 인터뷰 1958년"

translation.en: I'd heard of the stories of Cinderella singers like Elvis Presley,
translation.ko: 엘비스 프레슬리 같은 성공 신화를 듣긴 했지만

translation.en: but I never expected to be in one of those big payoffs myself.
translation.ko: 제가 그런 성공을 거두리라고는 전혀 예상 못 했어요

translation.en: "You Send Me" went straight up the charts, so he felt like,
translation.ko: '당신께서 날 보내셨죠'는 차트에서 승승장구했어요 그래서 샘은 원하는 걸 하고

translation.en: "I'm going to do what I wanna do, and I'm going to go where I wanna go."
translation.ko: 그래서 샘은 원하는 걸 하고 가고 싶은 데를 가리라 생각했죠

translation.en: Dick Clark from American Bandstand
was also a concert promoter all around the country,
and he hired Sam Cooke to come down to Atlanta and to do a live show.
translation.ko: 샘 쿡을 애틀랜타에서 하는 생방송에 초대했어요 "데이비드 워싱턴 라디오 진행자 / 친구"

translation.en: Dick Clark has such an impact in terms of how young folks listen to American music.
translation.ko: 젊은이들이 듣는 미국 음악에 딕 클라크가 미치는 영향력이 컸죠

translation.en: If you're Sam Cooke, you had to be on that show.
Sam was about the only black, or I should say negro singer at the time on the show,
translation.ko: 샘은 방송에 출연한 유일한 흑인 가수였고

translation.en: and the Klan members down there had a problem with that.
Suddenly, there are threats coming from the KKK
suggesting that perhaps you should not go up on that stage.
Ku Klux Klan had just bombed a Jewish synagogue down there,
translation.ko: "다이너마이트 폭탄에 애틀랜타 사원이 무너지다" KKK가 유대교 회당에 폭탄을 날려서

translation.en: so we know they meant business.
Sam told us Dick was thinking about canceling
'cause he was getting all of this threatening mail,
and people saying that they were gonna blow up the studio
if he had a-a nigger on, you know.
translation.ko: 검둥이를 출연시키면 스튜디오를 날려버리겠다고 사람들이 말했거든요 상황이 그랬어요

translation.en: That's just the way it was, you know.
Dick Clark did what a powerful white man would do.
translation.ko: 딕 클라크는 힘 있는 백인이라면 할만한 행동을 했어요

translation.en: He called the National Guard to keep people safe from the KKK,
translation.ko: KKK로부터 사람들을 보호하려고 주 방위군을 불렀어요

translation.en: but what Dick Clark didn't know that probably most black people in Atlanta knew
translation.ko: 그런데 애틀랜타에 있는 흑인들이 대부분 알았던 걸 딕은 몰랐죠

translation.en: that you probably couldn't trust the National Guard, either.
translation.ko: 주 방위군도 믿을 수 없을 거란 사실을요

translation.en: That's how pervasive this was.
[Dick] Welcome aboard. It's nice to have you here on a Saturday night.
translation.ko: 어서 오세요! 토요일 밤에 이렇게 나와 주셔서...

translation.en: He was angry, but he wasn't afraid to go nowhere, not Sam.
translation.ko: 샘은 화는 났지만 어디를 가든 두렵지 않았어요, 샘은요

translation.en: [Dick] It's Sam Cooke.
For Sam to go and do it anyway,
absolutely courageous, absolutely fearless,
because he was breaking boundaries, you know,
and I think Sam realized very early on "This is bigger than me."
translation.ko: 샘은 처음부터 자신에 국한된 문제가 아니란 걸 알았을 거예요

translation.en: What Sam Cooke would've said is that, "I'm a man,
translation.ko: 샘 쿡은 이렇게 말했을 거예요 '나는 남자다'

translation.en: and I'm a black man, and as a black man,
I have a responsibility to go on this show
translation.ko: '나는 흑인 남자로서 책임을 지고' '이 방송에 나가 어떤 벽이든 무너뜨릴 것이다'

translation.en: and bring down whatever walls I can bring--
translation.ko: '이 방송에 나가 어떤 벽이든 무너뜨릴 것이다'

translation.en: whatever boundaries I can help dissipate by showing that I am talented,
translation.ko: '내 재능을 보여줌으로써 벽을 허무는 일에 일조하겠다'

translation.en: I am skilled, I can compete with the best of them.
translation.ko: '나는 실력이 있고 최고의 가수들과 겨룰 수 있다'

translation.en: And in fact, there was an audience within white America
that was very interested in having me seen there."
Los Angeles, California, when you live in Cleveland, Ohio, is like a... a wonderland.
translation.ko: 오하이오 클리블랜드에 살다가 캘리포니아 LA에 가면 별천지죠

translation.en: He had moved out to California where all the movie stars,
so we looked at him as really had hit it big, you know.
He could be the forerunner.
[male announcer] The Arthur Murray Party.
To start the evening off, we have invited a young singer,
translation.ko: 오늘 저녁 첫 공연으로 젊은 가수를 초대했습니다

translation.en: who already has the most amazingly long list of hit recordings,
and he deserves every one of them.
It's Sam Cooke.
♪ Mary, Mary Lou ♪
♪ Why must you do ♪
♪ The things that you always do? ♪
Yeah.
I remember when he signed with RCA Victor.
translation.ko: 샘이 RCA 빅터와 계약했던 때가 기억납니다

translation.en: He says, "Man, can you believe
translation.ko: 엘비스 프레슬리 다음으로 음반 판매가 많다고

translation.en: that I'm number two under Elvis Presley in sales?"
translation.ko: 엘비스 프레슬리 다음으로 음반 판매가 많다고 믿어지냐며 물었죠

translation.en: We liked Elvis Presley, you know,
but I never thought I'd meet him.
One day, Sam said, "Hey, listen. Elvis is comin' over."
And we were like... "Sam's bullshittin' us, man.
translation.ko: 하루는 샘이 엘비스가 온다고 하더라고요 샘이 장난하는 줄 알았죠

translation.en: Elvis Presley ain't comin' over here to meet us, you know."
But sure enough, he came over to the studio,
and I thought like, "Man, Sam is out here. He knows everybody."
translation.ko: 샘은 이제 모르는 사람이 없구나 싶었어요

translation.en: ♪ We're havin' a party ♪
♪ Dancin' to the music ♪
People think of Sam Cooke primarily as a singer,
and I don't think he gets enough credit as a songwriter.
translation.ko: 작곡가로서는 충분히 인정받지 못하는 것 같아요

translation.en: You know, if you listen to a song like "Having a Party"...
♪ The Cokes are in the icebox... ♪
...you get these little snapshots of his life.
You wanna be at that party.
You feel the joy, the emotion of what's going on.
♪ Baby ♪
♪ We're out here on the floor ♪
Sam likes the idea of suddenly being in these exclusive circles
translation.ko: 힘 있는 유명 백인 인사들과 함께 지내는 걸

translation.en: with very powerful white people
who could help him, and he could learn from them.
It's kind of changing his idea of who he is and the influence he can have.
RCA built their own studio at Sunset and Vine,
translation.ko: RCA가 선셋 앤드 바인에 새 스튜디오를 지었어요

translation.en: and I was the first engineer they hired.
translation.ko: "알 슈밋 엔지니어 / 프로듀서" 제가 처음 고용된 엔지니어였어요

translation.en: Recording Sam was like catching fish in a barrel.
He wrote the songs. He sang the songs. He knew exactly what he wanted.
translation.ko: 자기가 곡을 쓰고 불렀으니 원하는 걸 명확히 알았죠

translation.en: We spent a lot of time together, and Sam got inside me, you know.
translation.ko: 함께 보내는 시간이 많았어요 샘은 저한테 형제나 마찬가지였죠

translation.en: He was more like a brother to me.
♪ The house I live in ♪
♪ A plot of earth ♪ ♪ A street ♪
He certainly had hit a point in his career where he could've just been playing
translation.ko: 뉴욕이나 로스 앤젤레스 시카고의 큰 나이트클럽에서

translation.en: the biggest nightclubs in New York, in Los Angeles, in Chicago.
It would've been easy for him to not go back to the South.
translation.ko: 남부로 돌아가지 않는 게 편했을 거예요

translation.en: But I think it was important for him to constantly keep that connection
translation.ko: 제 생각에 샘은 가수로서 청중들과 함께하는 것도

translation.en: for himself and for his audience,
translation.ko: 중요했지만 흑인 민권 운동에서 벌어지는 일을

translation.en: but to keep his finger on what was happening in the Civil Rights movement,
translation.ko: 중요했지만 흑인 민권 운동에서 벌어지는 일을 잘 파악하고 있는 것도 중요했을 거예요

translation.en: which wasn't happening the same way in the North or the West.
translation.ko: "흑인 차별 정책 타도" 북부나 서부가 남부 같지는 않았거든요

translation.en: ♪ That's America ♪
♪To ♪ ♪ Me ♪
My very first tour was with Sam Cooke.
We were in South Carolina,
and Sam says, "Everybody hungry?" We say, "Yeah."
translation.ko: 샘이 배고프냐고 물어서 다들 그렇다고 했죠

translation.en: We walked into this little place,
and we sat down and were asked to stand up.
translation.ko: 작은 식당에 들어가서 앉았어요 그런데 일어서라고 하더군요

translation.en: Oh, ok.
And we asked. I said, "Are you gonna take our orders?"
"You gotta shut up and wait till I get to you."
So me and my big mouth. I said, "You know what you can do?
Take that order and shove it." And we left.
Ten minutes later, there was a police officer...
that came to the bus...
and he stepped onto the bus.
And Sam said, "Can I help you?"
He said, "Yeah, we wanna know who those two gals were
that were rude to the waitress in the tavern house."
And Sam says, "First of all, we don't have gals on our bus.
We have ladies and gentlemen...
and this happens to be my bus. It's private property,
and I'm gonna ask you kindly to step off of it."
He thought about who he was
and those around him, who they were,
and that they were not going to take advantage of anybody that he cared about.
translation.ko: 그리고 자기가 아끼는 사람들을 함부로 못 하게 했어요

translation.en: I will never forget the day
I was unable to fulfill a one-night singing engagement in Georgia
translation.ko: 조지아에서 하기로 한 하룻밤 공연을 결국 못 했던 그날을 잊을 수 없을 겁니다 "샘 쿡 인터뷰 1960년"

translation.en: because I wouldn't sit in a Jim Crow bus,
translation.ko: 짐 크로 버스에 앉을 수가 없었거든요

translation.en: and because no white taxicab driver would take me from the airport to the city.
translation.ko: 백인 택시 기사는 아무도 나를 공항까지 데려다주지 않고

translation.en: And negro cab drivers were not permitted to bring their cabs into the airport.
translation.ko: 흑인 택시 기사는 공항에 가는 게 금지돼 있기 때문이었죠

translation.en: We used to play places in the South whereas the audiences,
translation.ko: 남부에서 공연을 했는데 청중들이 분리돼 있었어요

translation.en: even though they were integrated, they were segregated
because the white people would be upstairs,
and the black people would be downstairs or vice versa.
Or there'd be a big stage in the center of this arena,
and white people would be on one side, black people on the other,
translation.ko: 백인은 한쪽에 흑인은 다른 쪽에 앉았어요

translation.en: not even hardly lookin' at each other.
They had signs that said, "General Admission--2.50.
White spectators--a dollar and a half."
They'd sit up in the top of the places
translation.ko: 높은 데 앉아서 흑인들이 춤추는 걸 봤어요

translation.en: and watch the black people dance, you know. It was sickening.
translation.ko: 높은 데 앉아서 흑인들이 춤추는 걸 봤어요 끔찍했죠

translation.en: ♪ Someone really loves you ♪
♪ Guess who ♪
-♪ Guess who ♪ -There was a friend of... Jesse Belvin.
translation.ko: 누굴까? 누굴까요? 샘한테 제시 벨빈이라는 친구가 있었어요

translation.en: In February of 1960, Jesse played the first integrated show in Arkansas.
translation.ko: 1960년 2월에 아칸소에서 처음으로 차별 없는 공연을 했죠

translation.en: It was a big deal.
After the show was over, everybody left, went their separate ways,
translation.ko: 공연이 끝나고 모두 일어나 각자 갈길을 갔어요

translation.en: and about a half an hour out on the road, Jesse Belvin had a... head-on-head-on collision,
translation.ko: 30분쯤 차를 타고 가다가 제시 벨빈이 충돌 사고를 당했죠

translation.en: and it was fatal.
[Davis] Jesse Belvin, his wife, and three other people died.
translation.ko: 제시 벨빈과 아내 다른 세 명이 죽었습니다

translation.en: At first, we thought it was an accident,
but later, we found out that his tires had been cut by some locals in the area.
translation.ko: 처음에는 그냥 사고인 줄 알았는데 그 지역 주민들이 타이어에 구멍을 낸 게 후에 밝혀졌죠

translation.en: It was very, very shocking, you know, 'cause he had a great future ahead of him.
Of course it was a message.
I think Sam sort of saw that potential and wanted him to be a bigger star,
translation.ko: 샘은 제시의 가능성을 보고 큰 스타가 되기를 바랐는데

translation.en: and in that sort of terrible way, he was just sort of cut down. He was gone.
So now he wasn't just carrying Emmett Till,
he was also carrying Jesse Belvin with him and the things that he wanted to do
translation.ko: 제시 벨빈 사건까지 더해져서 샘은 인종차별을

translation.en: and the ways that he wanted to break down racism.
translation.ko: 허무는 일에 더 책임감을 느끼게 됐어요

translation.en: On May 12th, 1961,
we were playin' the Memphis City Auditorium.
Sam Cooke, Jackie Wilson. It was at least about 12 acts.
translation.ko: 샘 쿡과 재키 윌슨 적어도 12막은 넘었을 거예요

translation.en: So Sam asked the people that's in charge,
"Would the blacks sit at in the auditorium?"
The guy say, "Well, the back and the balcony, but they can't be up-front."
translation.ko: 뒤쪽이나 발코니에 앉을 수 있다고 했죠

translation.en: So Sam said, "Well..." He said, "I can't perform here."
translation.ko: 그랬더니 샘이 공연을 못 하겠다고 했어요

translation.en: Sam would say... "How does it look?
You know, I'm a star, and I'm known the world over...
but in my own home country...
I'm goin' along with some shit like this.
I'm gonna perform while my people is up in the balcony,
translation.ko: '내가 공연하는 동안 왜 흑인들은' '발코니 위에 있어야 하지? 아래층 사람들은 춤추고 즐기는데'

translation.en: and the people downstairs can dance and have a good time,
translation.ko: '발코니 위에 있어야 하지? 아래층 사람들은 춤추고 즐기는데'

translation.en: but my people can't dance?
I don't care what nobody else do. I ain't goin' for that shit."
translation.ko: '다른 사람이 어떻게 하든 난 못 맞춰주겠어'

translation.en: Sam gathered a meeting with all of the entertainers...
translation.ko: 샘이 모든 출연자들을 불러 회의를 열었고

translation.en: to boycott the show.
And everybody agreed,
"Yeah. Yeah, Sam. You're right. You're right. Yeah, we with you, man."
Went back to the hotel.
I went to Beetle Street first and got me some bourbon.
translation.ko: 비틀 스트리트에 먼저 가서 버번을 마셨어요

translation.en: I laid down, took a little nap.
And I got up later...
everybody-- I went round and knocked.
Everybody had gone and went back to the auditorium.
translation.ko: 모두 사라지고 없었어요 오디토리엄에 돌아간 거죠

translation.en: I went to Sam's room. He was in the room. Had on a-- never will forget.
translation.ko: 전 샘의 방에 갔어요 방에 있던 샘의 모습을 잊을 수가 없어요, 흰 셔츠를 입고

translation.en: He had on a white T-shirt, and he watching television.
translation.ko: 방에 있던 샘의 모습을 잊을 수가 없어요, 흰 셔츠를 입고 TV를 보고 있었어요

translation.en: And I says, "Sam, they all gone."
I said, "They said they was gonna stick with you," you know.
translation.ko: 제가 모두 갔다고 알렸죠 다들 함께한다더니 갔다고요

translation.en: He say, "Yeah, I know." He said, "But..." He said, "I'm not goin'."
translation.ko: 알지만 자기는 안 갈 거라고 했어요

translation.en: I'm not sure that Jesse Belvin's death
translation.ko: "유명 가수 분리된 청중석을 박차고 나오다" 제시 벨빈의 죽음이

translation.en: had an effect on the outcome of this boycott Sam was trying to do
translation.ko: 샘의 공연 보이콧이 그렇게 된 데 영향을 미쳤는진 모르겠어요

translation.en: because they was afraid what could happen to them.
He was takin' a big risk.
He could've been hurt or killed there, you know, at that time, you know.
translation.ko: 그 당시에 다치거나 죽을 수도 있었어요

translation.en: That's when I saw him in a different--
I had never seen that in him before.
And the hotel that time was the Lorraine.
Same hotel Martin Luther King was killed at some years later.
translation.ko: 몇 년 후에 마틴 루서 킹이 살해당한 그 호텔이었어요

translation.en: I've always detested people of any color, religion or nationality
who lack courage to stand up and be counted.
translation.ko: 용기 있게 나서지 못하는 사람들을 항상 싫어했어요 "샘 쿡 인터뷰 1960년"

translation.en: It is a difficult thing to do.
I hope, by refusing to play to a segregated audience,
translation.ko: 분리된 청중들이 있는 곳에서 공연을 거부한 일이

translation.en: it would help to break down racial segregation here.
translation.ko: 인종 차별이 사라지는 데 도움이 되기를 바랍니다

translation.en: And if I'm ever booked here again, it won't be necessary to do a similar thing.
translation.ko: 여기 다시 공연이 잡힌다고 해도 비슷한 일을 할 필요가 없겠죠

translation.en: ♪ Alabama's got me so upset ♪
♪ Tennessee made me lose my rest ♪
♪ Everybody knows about Mississippi ♪ ♪ God... damn ♪
translation.ko: 미시시피에에서 일어난 망할 사건은 모두가 알지

translation.en: During that time period, there were major artists,
Nina Simone comes to mind,
whose music would get banned from parts of the country
for some of their political stances.
And Sam was taking a big risk by saying, "I don't wanna play in a segregated space,"
translation.ko: 그러니 공연을 거부하는 건 큰 위험을 감수하는 일이었죠

translation.en: you know, particularly because he was a major star.
♪ That's the sound of the men ♪ ♪ Working on the chain gang ♪
Folks who didn't understand that Sam actually had some political concerns,
translation.ko: 샘이 정치적인 관심사가 있단 걸 이해 못 한 사람들은...

translation.en: you listen to a song like "Chain Gang,"
which just the rhythm of the song immediately would resonate
for generations of black folks who know about places like Parchman
translation.ko: 파치맨이나 다른 감옥 농장에 대해 아는 흑인 세대들은

translation.en: and other prison farms.
Yet you see these photos of Hugo and Luigi, his two producers, and Sam Cooke,
translation.ko: 그리고 프로듀서인 휴고와 루이지와 샘의 사진을 보면

translation.en: and they're comically dressed up in their black-and-whites and little caps,
translation.ko: 우스꽝스럽게 흑백 줄무늬 의상을 입고 있어요

translation.en: and so it's a way to take this song and bring it to mainstream white America,
translation.ko: 그렇게 해서 이 노래를 주류 백인들 사회에 들려주되

translation.en: but is also delivering a particular kind of critique
of what would've been a prison industrial complex of the late 1950s,
in which white audiences and black audiences hear that very, very differently.
translation.ko: 백인과 흑인은 각자 전혀 다르게 노래를 들었죠

translation.en: And there had been so few examples of black artists
who could code switch in that way
and be recognized in both the black world and the white world and still be men.
What white people have to do is try to find out in their own hearts
why it was necessary to have a nigger in the first place
translation.ko: 백인들은 진실되게 그 이유를 찾아야 합니다

translation.en: because I'm not a nigger.
I am a man.
If I'm not the nigger here...
and if you invented him, you, the white people, invented him...
then you got to find out why.
James Baldwin was one of his favorite authors.
He captured his attention.
Baldwin was a deep writer.
translation.ko: 볼드윈은 심오한 글을 썼어요 "짐 브라운 축구선수 / 운동가"

translation.en: I could understand...
Sam respecting him and pickin' up on his...
translation.ko: 볼드윈을 존경하고 그의 의미나 기여하는 바를

translation.en: meaning and what he's contributing.
He says, "You guys got to read."
And we weren't really carin' about no books or nothin' like that.
translation.ko: 저희는 책 같은 건 관심 없었거든요

translation.en: You know, we just wanted to sing and be on television and stuff.
translation.ko: 저희는 책 같은 건 관심 없었거든요 그냥 노래 부르고 TV에 나가고 싶을 뿐이었어요

translation.en: But he's like, "Man, that's not all of it."
He say, "You got to be knowledgeable."
The country has arbitrarily declared
that kinky hair and dark skin, wide nose and big lips
translation.ko: 곱슬한 머리, 어두운 피부색 뭉툭한 코, 큰 입은

translation.en: is a hideous thing to be afflicted with.
Sam was the one who started the black guys...
to wearin' fros.
♪ My baby couldn't do the cha-cha-cha ♪
-♪ I told her ♪ -Before that, our hair was processed,
translation.ko: 내가 말했어 그 전에는 머리를 매만져서

translation.en: and we were wearin' the slickback, the waves, and all that stuff like that.
translation.ko: 뒤로 싹 넘기거나 웨이브를 주거나 했어요

translation.en: Sam said, "No, that won't be me."
translation.ko: 샘은 그건 자기 스타일이 아니라며 거부했죠

translation.en: ♪ She likes her cha-cha-cha ♪
He went on TV, where his mother almost passed out because of the hair.
translation.ko: TV에 나왔는데 머리 때문에 어머니가 기절할 뻔했어요

translation.en: Heh. She did not like it, and she said, "Oh, look at my child."
Sam would talk to L.C. about,
"Man, you ought to get that process out your hair and let it go natural."
translation.ko: '머리 억지로 꾸미지 말고 그냥 자연스럽게 놔둬'

translation.en: He felt that it was part of his history... his culture.
translation.ko: 그게 자기 역사와 문화의 일부라고 생각했어요

translation.en: Switched over immediately.
All the black guys started gettin' the fros, you know.
translation.ko: 모든 흑인 남자들이 아프로를 하기 시작했어요

translation.en: Sam was a powerful man.
We were in Atlanta,
and in between concerts, he'd go to a newsstand and buy every magazine,
translation.ko: 콘서트 사이사이에 가판대에서 온갖 잡지를 샀어요

translation.en: and one day, he went and bought a boxing magazine.
And there was this guy.
I said, "Sam, this kid is the shit."
translation.ko: 제가 이 친구 진짜 물건이라고 했어요 "캐시어스 클레이의 은밀한 인생"

translation.en: He said, "All right, go get him."
translation.ko: "캐시어스 클레이의 은밀한 인생" 샘이 가서 데려오라더군요

translation.en: And I said, "What do you mean?" He said, "Tell him I sent you."
translation.ko: 제가 무슨 말이냐고 물었더니 본인이 보냈다고 전하래요

translation.en: I said, "Oh, my God."
I knock on his door. His brother Rudy cracks the door, and I said,
translation.ko: 문을 두드렸더니 형제인 루디가 문을 빼꼼히 열길래

translation.en: "I'm with the William Morris--" and he slams the door in my face.
translation.ko: 윌리엄 모리스와 일한다고 했어요 문을 쾅 닫아버리더군요

translation.en: And I said... "Sam Cooke."
And his mother said, "Let that boy in."
And his mother couldn't stop talking about Sam.
translation.ko: 어머니가 쉬지 않고 샘 이야기를 하더군요

translation.en: So, we made a deal to do an album...
and they really bonded.
Sam was God to him.
This is Sam Cooke. As you can see, like me, he's awful pretty.
-Ha ha. -And we are here now workin' on a record called "The Gang's All Here."
Would you like to give us a preview of this disc?
We'll do a lot better if we had the music here with us, but we'll try.
translation.ko: 음악이 있으면 더 잘할 텐데 어쨌거나 한번 해 볼게요

translation.en: -♪ Hey, hey, the gang's all here ♪ -[bangs beat on desk]
♪ Join in the fun ♪
♪ Hey, hey, the gang's all here ♪
♪ We gonna swing as one ♪
♪ Do it again now... ♪
The joy that they brought out of each other and the laughter--
they were showing a range of emotions together.
A kind of black male freedom, if you will.
That was not really--heh--
something we saw a lot of at that time in America.
You know, you always saw, up until that point,
these really harsh, stereotypical images of black people
translation.ko: 지나치고 전형적인 흑인 이미지들만 항상 봤거든요 우스꽝스러운 광대 같은 모습이나

translation.en: who were either, you know, buffoons and clowns
translation.ko: 항상 봤거든요 우스꽝스러운 광대 같은 모습이나

translation.en: and, you know, exaggerated facial expressions,
translation.ko: 항상 봤거든요 우스꽝스러운 광대 같은 모습이나 과장된 표정들이나 휘둥그레진 눈 등이었죠

translation.en: eyes bugging out, stuff like that.
♪ We gonna swing as one ♪
-How you like that? -Let's think about a young Michael Jackson
translation.ko: 어땠어요? 한번 생각해 보세요 어린 마이클 잭슨이나

translation.en: or a young Prince Rogers Nelson,
who would've been five or six years old,
sitting around the television watching these two young men.
translation.ko: TV 앞에 앉아서 두 젊은이를 본다면요

translation.en: What Ali and Sam Cooke represented was possibility.
translation.ko: 알리와 샘 쿡은 가능성을 선사해 보였죠

translation.en: Right? That there was another way for them to be in the world
translation.ko: 세상이 흑인을 억압하며 정해준 방식 외에

translation.en: other than the way that the world had dictated that black men had to be in the world.
translation.ko: 다른 방식으로 세상에 존재할 길이 있었던 것이죠

translation.en: It disturbed perceptions of what black masculinity was.
translation.ko: 흑인 남성성에 대한 인식을 뒤흔들어 놓았어요

translation.en: Cassius Clay very quietly was being mentored by a man named Malcolm X,
translation.ko: 맬컴 X라는 사람이 조용히 캐시어스의 멘토 역할을 했어요

translation.en: who was this fearless, and very much feared, black leader in America
who spoke, as he said, truth to power.
It's not hate to say that we were kidnapped and brought here. It's true.
translation.ko: 우리가 납치되어 여기 온 건 다름 아닌 사실입니다

translation.en: It's not hate to say we were Jim Crowed, discriminated, and segregated. It's true.
translation.ko: 우리가 차별 정책으로 차별받고 분리된 것은 다름 아닌 사실입니다

translation.en: Sam Cooke doesn't know Malcolm X yet,
translation.ko: 샘 쿡은 아직 맬컴 X를 몰랐지만

translation.en: but he's just seen how the Nation of Islam moves,
how they dealing with white supremacy,
He's, "Oh, this is kind of interesting." Right?
And he starts paying more attention to Malcolm X. They eventually become friends.
translation.ko: 맬컴 X를 더 눈여겨보기 시작했고 결국 친구가 됐어요

translation.en: Black men should have a hand in controlling
translation.ko: 흑인들이 손을 잡고 소위 말하는 흑인 사회의

translation.en: the economy of the so-called negro community.
translation.ko: 흑인들이 손을 잡고 소위 말하는 흑인 사회의 경제를 통제해야 합니다

translation.en: He should be developing the type of knowledge
that will enable him to own and operate the businesses,
translation.ko: 사업체를 소유하고 운영하는 지식들을 발전시키고 따라서 같은 민족인 흑인들을 위한 고용을

translation.en: and thereby be able to create employment for his own people, for his own kind.
translation.ko: 따라서 같은 민족인 흑인들을 위한 고용을 창출할 수 있어야 합니다

translation.en: Just like the Civil Rights movement was basically saying, "Why not us?"
translation.ko: 흑인 민권 운동처럼 우리도 할 수 있다는 모토였죠

translation.en: ♪ My man's got a heart-- ♪
Black blues musicians and jazz musicians and early black rock-'n'-roll artists

translation.en: who didn't really make anything from their music.
It was like sharecropping, where you do all the work, you do the labor--
translation.ko: 소작과 같았어요 온갖 노동을 다 해요

and then someone else reaps the benefits of it.
This publishers would rook songwriters out of their music.
Give 'em $25 and buy songs that became massive hits.
-♪ In the still of the-- ♪ -♪ Shoo-doo, dooby-doo ♪
Black musicians didn't get treated fairly.
translation.ko: 흑인 뮤지션들은 공정한 대우를 못 받았어요

translation.en: Instead of gettin' royalties, they would get... they'd get-- you'd get cocaine.
And that's just the way it was back then.
Disc jockey out of Philadelphia said,
"Sam, you know they're probably rippin' you off, RCA Records?"
translation.ko: 샘에게 RCA 레코드가 폭리를 취하는 것 같다며

translation.en: And he says, "I got a good CPA friend that I want you to meet."

translation.en: Allen Klein was an accountant in New York.
Klein had overheard conversations

translation.ko: 클라인은 RCA에서 받는 저작권료에 불만인 샘의 대화를 엿듣게 됐죠

translation.en: So Allen Klein audits RCA Victor...
translation.ko: 그래서 앨런 클라인이 RCA 빅터를 감사해서

translation.en: and comes up with a bunch of money for Sam.
Sam was extremely generous,
translation.ko: 샘은 인심이 후해서 늘 사람들을 챙겼죠

translation.en: always looked out for, not just his wife and children,
translation.ko: 샘은 인심이 후해서 늘 사람들을 챙겼죠 아내와 아이들 뿐만 아니라

translation.en: but also for his family members back in Chicago.

translation.en: He could've had a perfectly fine career as a singer,

translation.en: but it was always this idea there was something more.
He was always looking at what was gonna be next

translation.en: because he had this sense of the bigger picture.
translation.ko: 더 큰 그림에 대한 감이 있었으니까요

translation.en: J.W. Alexander was a member of the Pilgrim Travelers,

translation.en: and when that group disbanded,
he started a publishing company.
Said, "Sam, you're writing a lot of songs.
You need to own your publishing because that's where the money's at.
translation.ko: 독립 출판을 권했죠 그래야 돈도 생기고

translation.en: That's where the power's at."
Sam says, "Well, if we're gonna start a publishing company,
translation.ko: 이왕 출판사를 차릴 거면 음반사까지 차려서

translation.en: how about us starting a record company on top of it
and record our own artists?"
And that was the beginning of the partnership.
-[Sam] Johnnie? -Hey.
I want you to sing this real plain--
♪ But everybody's got a smile ♪
-♪ But everybody's got a smile ♪ -Right. We're in business.
translation.ko: - 그렇지만 모두가 웃고 있어 - 좋아, 이제 해 보자

translation.en: He was Berry Gordy before Berry Gordy

translation.en: when Sam started SAR Records with J.W. Alexander.
translation.ko: "루 애들러 음악 프로듀서" 샘이 JW 알렉산더와 SAR 레코드를 시작했을 때요

translation.en: The purpose of SAR Records was to give many of the gospel artists that Sam knew

translation.en: an opportunity to record pop records, perhaps cross over.
He had Johnnie Taylor and Mel Carter.
And I loved... The Valentinos. I loved them.
There was a song called, "I'm Lookin for a Love,"

♪ I'm lookin', I'm lookin', I'm lookin' ♪ ♪ I'm lookin' for a love to call my own ♪
♪ Someone to get up in the mornin' ♪
Sam Cooke and J.W. Alexander were both good businessmen,

translation.en: but I know it was all about...
tryin' to help these artists out.
I am aware that ownin' a record company
